question.title: Replace a checked exception with a runtime exception?

node.contents: Is [this](http://robaustin.wikidot.com/rethrow-exceptions) helpful?

astNode.text: Is [this](http://robaustin.wikidot.com/rethrow-exceptions) helpful?

node.contents: If you're irritated by nested stacktraces, you're gonna hate most frameworks and libraries, which tend to use them extensively. I'd just get used to it if I were you.

astNode.text: If you're irritated by nested stacktraces, you're gonna hate most frameworks and libraries, which tend to use them extensively. I'd just get used to it if I were you.

node.contents: @KazekageGaara, good one. I'd upvote that if you post it as an answer.

astNode.text: @KazekageGaara, good one. I'd upvote that if you post it as an answer.

node.contents: @artbristol I know, but I can do my part to minimize the problem and avoid 400 line stacktraces.

astNode.text: @artbristol I know, but I can do my part to minimize the problem and avoid 400 line stacktraces.

node.contents: Given that I basically want to eliminate checked exception usage and transform them to runtime exceptions, I would normally be doing something like this:

astNode.text: Given that I basically want to eliminate checked exception usage and transform them to runtime exceptions, I would normally be doing something like this:

elements.contents: try { file.read(); } catch (IOException e){ throw new RuntimeException(e); }

units.rawText: try { file.read(); } catch (IOException e){ throw new RuntimeException(e); }

node.contents: There are several disadvantages to doing this, but the one that irritates me the most is that my runtime exception would contain a nested stacktrace. Basically I would like to re-throw the "IOException" as a RuntimeException (or "IORuntimeException") with the original message and stacktrace, so I can avoid the useless nested stacktrace. The "fact" that I have re-thrown the exception somewhere in the middle seems like just useless noise to me.

astNode.text: There are several disadvantages to doing this, but the one that irritates me the most is that my runtime exception would contain a nested stacktrace. Basically I would like to re-throw the "IOException" as a RuntimeException (or "IORuntimeException") with the original message and stacktrace, so I can avoid the useless nested stacktrace. The "fact" that I have re-thrown the exception somewhere in the middle seems like just useless noise to me.

node.contents: Is this possible ? Is there any library that does this ?

astNode.text: Is this possible ? Is there any library that does this ?

node.contents: Follow up from my comment. Here's an article that has to throw some light on the issue. It uses sun.misc.Unsafe to rethrow exceptions without wrapping them.

astNode.text: Follow up from my comment. Here's an article that has to throw some light on the issue. It uses sun.misc.Unsafe to rethrow exceptions without wrapping them.

node.contents: Fair enough, but it's too much of a hack to me. I'd rather just do it myself somewhere

astNode.text: Fair enough, but it's too much of a hack to me. I'd rather just do it myself somewhere

node.contents: I doubt if there is a non-hacky solution to the problem you are trying to solve.

astNode.text: I doubt if there is a non-hacky solution to the problem you are trying to solve.

node.contents: Project Lombok allows you to disable checked exceptions altogether.

astNode.text: Project Lombok allows you to disable checked exceptions altogether.

node.contents: The problem with this approach is that it cannot be generalized for any `Exception` type, and thus causes too much boilerplate and code duplication.

astNode.text: The problem with this approach is that it cannot be generalized for any `Exception` type, and thus causes too much boilerplate and code duplication.

node.contents: Well, you can always do [this](http://ideone.com/9OOwd).

astNode.text: Well, you can always do [this](http://ideone.com/9OOwd).

node.contents: Yes, but the type information is lost. Only if Java had reified generics... then we could have done this with generics.

astNode.text: Yes, but the type information is lost. Only if Java had reified generics... then we could have done this with generics.

node.contents: An interesting aspect of this response is that it does not really work ;) "fillInStackTrace" is called from the the throwable constructor, meaning the member variable in the subclass hasnt been initialized.

astNode.text: An interesting aspect of this response is that it does not really work ;) "fillInStackTrace" is called from the the throwable constructor, meaning the member variable in the subclass hasnt been initialized.

node.contents: Ah, so remove @Override ... fillInStackTrace then?

astNode.text: Ah, so remove @Override ... fillInStackTrace then?

elements.contents: class IORuntimeException extends RuntimeException { final IOException ioex; public IORuntimeException(IOException ioex) { this.ioex = ioex; } @Override public String getMessage() { return ioex.getMessage(); } @Override public StackTraceElement[] getStackTrace() { return ioex.getStackTrace(); } //@Override // ... }

node.contents: (Full class available here, as produced by Eclipse "Generate Delegate Methods" macro.)

astNode.text: (Full class available here, as produced by Eclipse "Generate Delegate Methods" macro.)

node.contents: Usage:

astNode.text: Usage:

elements.contents: try { ... } catch (IOException ioex) { throw new IORuntimeException(ioex); }

units.rawText: try { ... } catch (IOException ioex) { throw new IORuntimeException(ioex); }

node.contents: sounds like you actually NEED checked Exceptions

astNode.text: sounds like you actually NEED checked Exceptions

node.contents: If you're considering the other answer's use of Unsafe (I recommend not, but anyway), another option is to abuse generics to throw a checked exception with this evil pair of methods (from http://james-iry.blogspot.co.uk/2010/08/on-removing-java-checked-exceptions-by.html):

astNode.text: If you're considering the other answer's use of Unsafe (I recommend not, but anyway), another option is to abuse generics to throw a checked exception with this evil pair of methods (from http://james-iry.blogspot.co.uk/2010/08/on-removing-java-checked-exceptions-by.html):

elements.contents: @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") private static <T extends Throwable, A> A pervertException(Throwable x) throws T { throw (T) x; } public static <A> A chuck(Throwable t) { return Unchecked. <RuntimeException, A>pervertException(t); }

units.rawText: @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") private static <T extends Throwable, A> A pervertException(Throwable x) throws T { throw (T) x; } public static <A> A chuck(Throwable t) { return Unchecked<RuntimeException, A>pervertException(t); }

node.contents: You might also check out com.google.common.base.Throwables.getRootCause(Throwable) and just print its (root) stack trace.

astNode.text: You might also check out com.google.common.base.Throwables.getRootCause(Throwable) and just print its (root) stack trace.
